channel.title: Vba
channel.description:
Ok people I need some serious help here, anyone who knows some VBA/VB doesn't matter. Now, apparantly in VBA, you don't have the option to use global variables. For example, In my form_onload handler I had this:
[code] Dim whatever As Boolean
then I had below that
whatever = True[/code]
Now, on the shitheadbutton_click handler I had this:
[code] If whatever = True Then MsgBox go fuck yourself ElseIf whatever = False MsgBox don't fuckyourself End If[/code]
Now, basicly I changed the true on the onload to false to see if this has any effect and BAM, no, apparantly it didn't look at the true/false on the onload handler. Also, that BAM, the result I get from this is just the second (false) msgbox. Now I was suprised so I decided to see what happend when I just removed the onload handler completely leaving just in the whole source this:
[code] Public Sub shitheadbutton_Click()
If whatever = True Then MsgBox go fuck yourself ElseIf whatever = False MsgBox don't fuckyourself End If End Sub[/code]
AND IF FUCKING KEPT DISPLAYING THE SAME SHIT OVER AND OVER, IT KEPS DISPPLAYING THE FUCKING FALSE VALUE I DID NOT EVEN TOLD HIM THAT THE BOOLAEN WHATEVER EXISTS, <---- sorry about that, now where was I, oh yeah, I didn't tell microsoft that the boolean whatever existed so normally a normal programming language would give me an error telling whatever does not exist but microsoft does't like to do that. Now please anyone, help, I need to get this shit working by tomorrow for school.

[/quote]
sigh This question is asked in every single thread about VB or VBA.[/quote]Good thing I don’t read every single thread about VB or VBA then, eh?

item.title: Vba
item.dc:creator: @MistaBigBoss MistaBigBoss
item.description:
@MistaBigBoss wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:2, topic:394273”]They still teach Visual Basic?[/quote]Yes they do and It’s fucking annoying.

Actully they give us VBA not VB, VBA is for automating shit in access, excel, etc etc.

BUT I FIGURED IT OUT, I had to set the variables to Public to make them global.

As in,

Public whatever As Boolean yeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee

Read full topic

item.title: Vba
item.dc:creator: @MistaBigBoss MistaBigBoss
item.description:
@MistaBigBoss wrote:

Ok people I need some serious help here, anyone who knows some VBA/VB doesn’t matter. Now, apparantly in VBA, you don’t have the option to use global variables. For example, In my form_onload handler I had this:

[code]
Dim whatever As Boolean

then I had below that

whatever = True[/code]

Now, on the shitheadbutton_click handler I had this:

If whatever = True Then MsgBox go fuck yourself ElseIf whatever = False MsgBox don't fuckyourself End If

Now, basicly I changed the true on the onload to false to see if this has any effect and BAM, no, apparantly it didn’t look at the true/false on the onload handler. Also, that BAM, the result I get from this is just the second (false) msgbox. Now I was suprised so I decided to see what happend when I just removed the onload handler completely leaving just in the whole source this:

[code]
Public Sub shitheadbutton_Click()

If whatever = True Then
MsgBox go fuck yourself
ElseIf whatever = False
MsgBox don’t fuckyourself
End If
End Sub[/code]

AND IF FUCKING KEPT DISPLAYING THE SAME SHIT OVER AND OVER, IT KEPS DISPPLAYING THE FUCKING FALSE VALUE I DID NOT EVEN TOLD HIM THAT THE BOOLAEN WHATEVER EXISTS, <---- sorry about that, now where was I, oh yeah, I didn’t tell microsoft that the boolean whatever existed so normally a normal programming language would give me an error telling whatever does not exist but microsoft does’t like to do that. Now please anyone, help, I need to get this shit working by tomorrow for school.

Read full topic
